title: Can I publish a summary of another book as my own kindle ebook without copyright problems? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you write a book whose express purpose is to enable other people to avoid having to buy some other book, by providing key information that is in that book, that speaks to the very heart and soul of intellectual property law. Even if you don’t infringe on copyright in a technical sense, (copying text exactly), there’s no question that you could and would be sued. You’d be making money from someone else’s creative work, and causing them direct financial loss by deliberately removing incentive for people to buy their book. It don’t get much more sue-able than that. If you think what you are doing is legit because of the way you are handling it, then write to the authors and ask for permission. That’s all you need, to publish anything. If you do’nt feel comfortable telling them what the project is about…then that kind of answers your question, doesn’t it?

perhaps it may be interesting to consult amazon kindle here. According to the below, it would seem they don’t have a problem with it. But maybe, if someone does decide to come after you, they won’t do much/anything to defend you. “If you're publishing a companion book based on an original work, such as a summary, study guide or analysis, begin your title with the term "Summary," "Study Guide," or "Analysis." When designing your companion book cover, make sure the term "Summary," "Study Guide," or "Analysis" appears before the title of the original work in a font at least as large as the rest of the title.” Get help with self-publishing your book to Amazon's Kindle Store

I am not a copyright lawyer, but this sounds sticky to me. In writing novels, I and other authors have wished to include a few lines from songs in our books, and the answer we have come up with is that you can reference a song by its title, you can talk ABOUT the song, but you cannot QUOTE the song.  You can write a book ABOUT software engineering that is more concise than other books that are available, but marketing a book as a summary of someone else's work, which would then entail copious quotes of that work, is bound to get you into trouble.
